[Content truncated]... in 2010. In a 2014 interview, Hathaway said Kate was her "favorite" princess. Princess Kate in Norfolk, England, December 25, 2023. And (inset) Anne Hathaway as Kate in a sketch for "Saturday Night Live," in 2010. In a 2014 interview, Hathaway said Kate was her "favorite" princess. Stephen Pond/Getty Images/Saturday Night Live/YouTube
Uploaded to  by user, milfssb, on April 14,  of Hathaway praising Kate has been edited together with clips from the princess' public engagement, receiving over 250,000 views in less than 24 hours.
Hathaway's comment was taken from a 2014 interview with _Good Morning America_, in which she was asked who her favorite princess was, considering her roles in the _Princess Diaries_.
After taking a moment to consider her answer, the star responded: "Right now, I think my favorite princess is ...I'm gonna go with Kate Middleton. I think she's lovely and she makes me very happy and that royal wedding just could not be beat."
>  anne hathaway saying her favorite princess is kate middleton might be my new favorite thing         
Read more
*   
*   
*   
This was not the first time Hathaway discussed Kate in an interview. Following her _Saturday Night Live_ parody of the princess—dressed in a replica of her famous blue engagement dress, copy of 's engagement ring and the royal's famous blown-out hairstyle—the star told a British newspaper she'd happily consider playing Kate in a movie.
"I haven't really thought about it before but yes, why not," she told _The Sun_ on the prospect of playing the real life royal in a biopic. "She's great. It's such a fairytale."
Captioned "Anne Hathaway saying her favorite princess is Kate Middleton might be my new favorite thing," the viral TikTok video has received over 45,000 likes on the platform, so far, and over 190 comments, many of which have praised both Kate and the Hollywood star.
"THEY BOTH ARE SO BEAUTIFUL, I CAN'T," wrote one user.
"Anne and Kate, the duo I never knew I needed," posted another, with a further comment adding: "And Anne Hathaway did a snl \ playing Kate."
_James Crawford-Smith is_ Newsweek_'s royal reporter, based in London. You can find him on X (formerly ) at  and read his stories on_...[Content truncated]

Set to "Sun Bleached Flies" by Ethel Cain (proving she's already a bona fide TikTok girlie), Hathaway had no trouble poking fun at herself, highlighting those , her tense encounters with paparazzi and her propensity to .
On the flip side, she also gave herself some flowers for some of her best looks:  at the 2023 Met Gala,  for a Valentino show in Rome, and her  look in Venice.
Anne Hathaway at the 2023 Met Gala. - John Shearer/WireImage
As for some of her favorite roles over the last few years, the actress highlights "channeling her Scorpio energy" in _The Witches_, teaming up with  in _WeCrashed_, and finally, producing and premiering her new rom-com, .
Hathaway concludes the epic video with a funny candid clip where she "realizes" the one thing she didn't do over the last few years: "I forgot to join TikTok!"

[Content truncated]... carpet

!
Met Gala employee gives piece of carpet to onlookers outside The Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday in New York.Gilbert Flores / Variety via Getty Images
!
People gather outside the 2024 Met Gala Monday in New York.Noam Galai / GC Images
Some fans are already gathering outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art in hopes of catching a glimpse of celebrities when they start walking the carpet later this afternoon.
When was the first Met Gala?
----------------------------
]
Before it became the most glamorous and star-studded night in fashion, the Met Gala started off as a fundraising benefit attended primarily by New York City socialites, according to .
The first gala, which cost $50 per ticket, was held in December 1948 to raise money for the Met Costume Institute. It was a midnight dinner at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan.
It wasn’t until decades later that the Met Gala began to resemble the iconic cultural event it is today.
Zendaya's highly anticipated Met Gala return
--------------------------------------------
]
Zendaya, who is a co-chair of the Met Gala, is returning to the event for the first time since 2019. Notably, her last Met Gala look five years ago was a Cinderella-inspired gown that changed color with the wave of a wand.
!
Zendaya and Law Roach attend The 2019 Met Gala at Metropolitan Museum of Art on May 6, 2019 in New York. John Shearer / Getty Images
The actress is having quite the year, with her "Challengers" and "Dune: Part Two" press tour looks turning her into even more of a red carpet force of nature.
Zendaya’s longtime stylist, Law Roach, will be styling her once again for tonight's affair.
The Mark Hotel and The Carlyle: Where celebrities get ready
-----------------------------------------------------------
]
Kaetlyn Liddy is a newsroom coordinator for NBC News Digital.
New York City has no shortage of hotels, but The Carlyle or The Mark Hotel are usually the go-to spots for celebrities as they get ready for the Met Gala.
Both hotels are conveniently located on the Upper East Side, within a few blocks of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Mark is home to the largest penthouse suite in the U.S. and the unofficial "pre-red carpet," where fans and photographers gather to catch the first glimpses of stars like Kim Kardashian, Gigi Hadid and Anna Wintour on their way to the Met Gala.
"Timing is essential on the day," The Mark's General M...[Content truncated]

content.content:
I spent $130 to get my colors professionally analyzed and learned I've been wearing the wrong shades my entire life
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Updated
2024-03-11T20:41:55Z
!
Angle down icon An icon in the shape of an angle pointing down.
I had an expert tell me which colors I should and should not be wearing and it rocked my world. Paige DiFiore
*   I paid a color analyst to  and which make me look my worst.
*   With photos of me, she determined my undertone (warm) and season (autumn) — I was wrong about both.
*   The expert also shared tips and tricks for finding your season at home for free.
I had never given the colors I wear much thought until a recent TikTok effect made me reflect on my choices.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
!(blob:https://www.businessinsider.com/3f711207ef1410619eb8e4b36b1349ed)
White sneakers are probably the one consistent part of my wardrobe. Paige DiFiore
Like most people, there are a few colors I love to wear and some I don't like as much, but I've never thought about which ones flatter me.
That is until I discovered a TikTok effect —   — that brought me into the magical, somewhat confusing world of seasons and colors.
The idea is that each person has a "season" of colors that look best on them — winter, spring, summer, or autumn — based on their eye color, hair color, and skin tone.
I made many TikToks with the effect and solicited opinions from everyone in my life, but my "season" remained a mystery.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
!(blob:https://www.businessinsider.com/3f711207ef1410619eb8e4b36b1349ed)
The filter made me think I was definitely not an autumn. TikTok
The TikTok effect left me confused — in my opinion, the autumn palette made me look sickly, while the winter and spring ones made me look my best.
I also wasn't sure how accurate the effect was. The person who created it appears to primarily be a TikTok effect creator, not a professional color analyst.
I played with the TikTok effect for hours, but I still couldn't figure out the colors I should be wearing.
A peek inside my closet also left me feeling confused.
------------------------------------------------------
!(blob:https://www.businessinsider.com/3f711207ef1410619eb8e4b36b1349ed)
On the left, I borrowed salmon, light brown...[Content truncated]

QA.Question: Was there any official statement or reliable news source confirming the authenticity of the TikTok video featuring Anne Hathaway?
QA.Answer: There has been no official statement or reliable news source confirming the authenticity of the TikTok video featuring Anne Hathaway sharing the joke "What is 6.9? A good thing ruined by a period." In fact, multiple reputable sources indicate that the video is fake and generated using artificial intelligence. Specifically, an article from Indy100 clearly states that the viral TikTok clip claiming to show Hathaway making the joke is artificial and does not represent a real interaction on "The Daily Show" with Jon Stewart. This assertion is further supported by user comments pointing out the video's artificial nature, acknowledging that it was created using AI technology, which adds to the reasons to doubt its authenticity.
